title.narrative: Building inclusive political representation in Rivers State

description.narrative: This project will aim to increase political participation and representation by women and young people in Rivers state in the run up to 2023 election and secure policy commitments and actions by political aspirants, representatives, and political parties, in response to the demands of women and young people

"At least 300 young people and women (aiming for at least 65% female, and at least 50% aged below 35) who will have increased skills, experience and networks as a result of their participation in the campaigning, policy and influencing programme, increasing their opportunities to advance their ambitions in politics and/or social movements. Out of this number, 240 community advocacy members (10 per community) and 60 beneficiaries drawn from civil society, activists, influencers, the media and students will be engaged to mobilise citizens and actively participate in campaigns to further their organisational and social objectives.
The indirect beneficiaries of the project are women and young people across Rivers state, and particularly those in the four focus LGAs, who are intended to benefit through increased opportunities for political participation (including campaigns to encourage increased voter registration and transfer) and an improved response by those in positions of power to policy priorities relevant to them. The estimated total population of Rivers is 7.3m (NBS, 2016) and for the four LGAs: Obio/Akpor (649,000), Port Harcourt (756,600), Okrika (312,300) and Ogu-Bolo (105,800). While up-to-date and detailed population data do not exist, it is reasonable to assume the target demographic (young people aged 18-35 and women aged 18 and over) comprise at least a third of the population. "

title.narrative: Outcome: To initiate a sustained process of increasing female and youth representation in politics and improved engagement with political representatives in Rivers State via: - Increasing political engagement by women and young people in the run up to 2023 election - Securing commitments and actions by political aspirants, representatives, and political parties, and Rivers State Government (including the State House of Assembly) which respond to the policy demands of women and young people in the areas of political representation, unemployment and soot pollution

description.narrative: This entails the the government, political parties, and INEC are influenced by project to initiate or implement existing policies, take actions or commitments that promote women, young people and PwDs inclusion and participation in decision-making and democratic processes.

The 4 project target LGAs forms 36% (445,400) of potential registrants to be targeted by INEC in Rivers State. Only 5% of the potential registrants was captured as at baseline

title.narrative: "OC Indicator 6. Commitments and actions taken by INEC to facilitate greater voter registration and transfers by women and youth voters "

Output 1: Women and young people in Rivers state, with a particular focus on four local government areas, are supported to become more politically active and engaged with the democratic process in advance of the 2023 elections.
Indicator 1.1: Number of frontline ambassadors (women and young people) who successfully complete leadership, campaigning, policy and influencing skills training (disaggregated by gender, age)

comment.narrative: At baseline, the porject was still identifying and selecting ambassadors
Train 300 frontline ambassadors

298 frontline ambassadors (51% female, 49% Male; also 66% between 35 years and below) drawn from 24 communities across project target LGAs, and CSOs were sucessfully trained on leadership, campaigning, policy and influencing skills.
72% of the frontline ambassadors demonstrated improved knowledge on leadership campaign, policy and influencing skills.This was measured via pre-and-post knowledge test

title.narrative: Output Indicator 1.4: Estimated reach of public campaign activities (e.g. in person, via radio, social media) to promote voter registration, transfer and participation (disaggregated by communication channel)

comment.narrative: At baseline, the project are yet to implement campaign strategy
Directly reach at least 5000 and indirectly 3,000,000 Rivers state citizens on voter CVR through project campaign channels

SDN has used both traditional and digital media platforms to sensitise Rivers State citizens on the ongoing Continuous Voter Registration (CVR), our weekly radio programme which airs on NigeriaInfo Fm 92.3 and Wazobia Fm 94.1 has indirectly reach at least an average of 2,000,000 listeners that tunes in weekly to the radio programme across the two radio stations used for the project campaign.

title.narrative: Output Indicator 1.3: Number of frontline ambassadors (disaggregated by gender, age) who actively participate in the delivery of the campaign activities (e.g. by producing social media content, attendance at advocacy activities)

comment.narrative: Campaign was not ran at baseline
At least 240 frontline (50% women) ambassadors are activitly involved in the delivery of the campaign activities

240 ambassadors from 24 communities (composing 81% of the trained frontline ambassadors) activiely engaged in sensitizing and mobilizing their community members to register in the ongoing CVR process. So far the project has recorded 34 instances where the community ambassadors either sensitized or mobilized citizens to register in the ongoing CVR in Rivers State.
The ambassadors have directly reached and sensitized above 27,000 individuals across the 24 target commuties and has influenced an average of 500 persons to register to get PVC for the 2023 election in Rivers State

SDN in collaboration with women groups in Rivers State such as GADA, Kebetkache, ALIVE, Mother of Good Counsel, We-YOU Ambassadors, male champions estimated at about 60 persons marked the IWD with a peace walk to protest the rejection of 5 Gender Bills by the NASS. The group made significant stops at the Rivers State Judiciary, the NUJ and finally the Rivers Sytate House of Assembly. The group was addressed by the Speaker of the House who showed support and commitment to improve women represenattion in political administration in the State
